title.native: ダーリン・イン・ザ・フランキス

description:
The distant future: Humanity established the mobile fort city, Plantation, upon the ruined wasteland. Within the city were pilot quarters, Mistilteinn, otherwise known as the “Birdcage.” That is where the children live... Their only mission in life was the fight. Their enemies are the mysterious giant organisms known as Kyoryu. The children operate robots known as FRANXX in order to face these still unseen enemies. Among them was a boy who was once called a child prodigy: Code number 016, Hiro. One day, a mysterious girl called Zero Two appears in front of Hiro. “I’ve found you, my Darling.”

(Source: Crunchyroll)

tags.name: Orphan
tags.description: Prominently features a character that is an orphan.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Robots
tags.description: Prominently features humanoid machines.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Found Family
tags.description: Features a group of characters with no biological relations that are united in a group providing social support.

tags.name: Psychosexual
tags.description: Work that involves the psychological aspects of sexual impulses.

tags.name: Femdom
tags.description: Female Dominance. Features sexual acts with a woman in a dominant position.

tags.name: Cohabitation
tags.description: Features two or more people who live in the same household and develop a romantic or sexual relationship.

tags.name: Kaiju
tags.description: Prominently features giant monsters.

tags.name: Monster Girl
tags.description: Prominently features a female character who is part-monster.

tags.name: Lost Civilization
tags.description: Featuring a civilization with few ruins or records that exist in present day knowledge.

tags.name: Memory Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) who has had their memories altered.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Demons
tags.description: Prominently features malevolent otherworldly creatures.

tags.name: Environmental
tags.description: Concern with the state of the natural world and how humans interact with it.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Clone
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is an artificial exact copy of another organism.

tags.name: Monster Boy
tags.description: Prominently features a male character who is a part-monster.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Family Life
tags.description: Centers around the activities of a family unit.

tags.name: Virginity
tags.description: Features a male character who has never had sexual relations (until now).

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Netorare
tags.description: Netorare is what happens when the protagonist gets their partner stolen from them by someone else. It is a sexual fetish designed to cause sexual jealousy by way of having the partner indulge in sexual activity with someone other than the protagonist.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Survival
tags.description: Centers around the struggle to live in spite of extreme obstacles.

tags.name: Yandere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is obsessively in love with another, to the point of acting deranged or violent.

tags.name: Time Skip
tags.description: Features a gap in time used to advance the story.

tags.name: Marriage
tags.description: Centers around marriage between two or more characters.

tags.name: Tsundere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who acts cold and hostile in order to mask warmer emotions.

tags.name: Drawing
tags.description: Centers around the art of drawing, including manga and doujinshi.

tags.name: Medicine
tags.description: Centered around the activities of people working in the field of medicine.

tags.name: Reincarnation
tags.description: Features a character being born again after death, typically as another person or in another world.

tags.name: Aviation
tags.description: Regarding the flying or operation of aircraft.

tags.name: Agriculture
tags.description: Prominently features agriculture practices.

tags.name: Fishing
tags.description: Centers around the sport of fishing.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Pandemic
tags.description: Prominently features a disease prevalent over a whole country or the world.

title.native: ダーリン・イン・ザ・フランキス
だーりん・いん・ざ・ふらんきす！

alternative: Zero Zero One (ゼロゼロイチ)

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1515331173983330306)

Nishigori graduated from the Toei Animation Institute and joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) as an in-betweener but he rapidly distinguished himself as a key animator. He was inspired to enter the field because he liked [Hidenori Matsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/107672/) and [Takeshi Honda](https://anilist.co/staff/103303/)'s drawings.

His first major role was serving as character animation director for [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/Gunbuster-2-Diebuster/), with the task of adapting [Yoshiyuki Sadamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/98158/Yoshiyuki-Sadamoto)'s character designs for animation. This experience led him to become one of the main character designers at the studio, designing the iconic characters for [Gurren Lagann](https://anilist.co/anime/2001/).

He left Gainax to have his debut as director on [The Idolm@ster](https://anilist.co/anime/10278/The-Idol-Master/), a personal passion project since he's a great fan of the series. Several Gainax staff followed Nishigori to [A-1 Pictures](https://anilist.co/studio/561/) and worked on the series, alongside staff from newly formed [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/Trigger).

In 2018 he directed his original project [Darling in the Franxx](https://anilist.co/anime/99423/), once again reuniting with his Gainax friends spread among [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/), Trigger and [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/).

More recently he worked as character designer and chief animation director for [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/)'s final Evangelion installment, [Evangelion: 3.0+1.0 Thrice Upon A Time](https://anilist.co/anime/3786/Evangelion-3010-Thrice-Upon-A-Time/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/371954143)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1515331173983330306)

He was inspired to enter the field because he liked [Hidenori Matsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/107672/) and [Takeshi Honda](https://anilist.co/staff/103303/)'s drawings.

His first major role was serving as character animation director for [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/Gunbuster-2-Diebuster/), with the task of adapting [Yoshiyuki Sadamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/98158/Yoshiyuki-Sadamoto)'s character designs for animation. This experience led him to become one of the main character designers at the studio, designing the iconic characters for [Gurren Lagann](https://anilist.co/anime/2001/).

He left Gainax to have his debut as director on [The Idolm@ster](https://anilist.co/anime/10278/The-Idol-Master/), a personal passion project since he's a great fan of the series. Several Gainax staff followed Nishigori to [A-1 Pictures](https://anilist.co/studio/561/) and worked on the series, alongside staff from newly formed [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/Trigger).

In 2018 he directed his original project [Darling in the Franxx](https://anilist.co/anime/99423/), once again reuniting with his Gainax friends spread among [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/), Trigger and [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/).

More recently he worked as character designer and chief animation director for [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/)'s final Evangelion installment, [Evangelion: 3.0+1.0 Thrice Upon A Time](https://anilist.co/anime/3786/Evangelion-3010-Thrice-Upon-A-Time/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/林直孝_(脚本家%29)

A scriptwriter and game scenario writer.

_Note: Not to be confused with the [animator/director](https://anilist.co/staff/110663/)._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/589238508)

Originating from [Artland](https://anilist.co/studio/8/), currently affiliated with [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/CloverWorks).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/589238508)

Originating from [Artland](https://anilist.co/studio/8/), currently affiliated with [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/CloverWorks).

[Twitter (shiimai)](https://twitter.com/shiimai) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=hiroyuki_imaishi+) 

Hiroyuki Imaishi was born in 1971, in Tokyo. He joined studio Gainax after graduating from Tama University of Arts. Imaishi later left the studio to establish his own studio, Trigger, where he still works to this day.

Imaishi made a name for himself on *Hideaki Anno*'s [Kareshi Kanojo no Jijou](https://anilist.co/anime/145/Kareshi-Kanojo-no-Jijou/). He did key animation and storyboards for several episodes, with episode 19 being a standout for its unorthodox paper cutout animation. His presence injected some stylized levity into Anno's shoujo drama.

Imaishi started as an animator heavily influenced by [Masahito Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/138566/Masahito-Yamashita) and [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/Yoshinori-Kanada). He draws 
with a similar warping of perspective and with characters snapping into discrete poses, mixed with cartoony devices reminiscent of A Pro's work on [Dokonjo Gaeru](https://anilist.co/anime/5618/Dokonjou-Gaeru/), of which Imaishi is a fan. He also tends to draw his characters enveloped in speedlines, with strongly defined eyes and eyebrows, rectangular jawlines, and gummy, gritted teeth. His cuts are willfully limited, eliminating transitions between poses and using fast looping for comedic effect.

Imaishi became one of Gainax' premier directors after Kare Kano. His directorial aesthetic is heavily informed by his animation. Elisions of graphic space become elisions of cinematic space and time.The interplay of moving and still planes, forceful use of text, and extreme variations in size are other major components of his direction. His shot compositions are usually very busy due to crunching in as much of his characters into the frame as possible, and he has no problem reducing action scenes to pure visual abstraction, like rendering clashing figures as a few pencil lines. He is known to employ [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/Osamu-Dezaki)-esque tricks like triple takes and postcard shots in his work. His storyboards are rough, improvised, and lacking in detail. He's a fan of American director [Robert Rodriguez](https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001675/) and [John Woo](https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000247/), and loves referencing classic anime and film in his works.

His first solo directorial effort was the Production I.G. OVA [Dead Leaves](https://anilist.co/anime/974/Dead-Leaves/) which would set the stage for Imaishi's later works: crude, anarchic, and heterogeneous characters positioned against a homogenizing totalitarian force. Dead Leaves uses pillarboxing and text in a manner recalling stylized comic books. Imaishi served as character designer and animation director on the OVA so the animation is steeped in his neo-Kamada idiom more than any of his other works.

Imaishi left Gainax and formed studio Trigger with [Masahiko Otsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/108023/Masahiko-Ootsuka) in 2011, bringing over several major animators to the new studio. His debut TV work with Trigger was 2013's [Kill la Kill](https://anilist.co/anime/18679/Kill-la-Kill/), that similarly to Gurren Lagann, freely and extensively referenced anime history. Despite being a broadly popular series overseas, it is Imaishi's most controversial work to date, not only for its extreme levels of fanservice, but also because it suffered damaging production problems: rewrites of the script, cost cutting animation shortcuts, and a restrictive schedule. 

[Source](https://camonte.wordpress.com/2014/10/06/hiroyuki-imaishi/)

__[Profile (Legendoor)](http://www.legendoor.com/artist/%E6%A9%98%E9%BA%BB%E7%BE%8E)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/AsamiTachibana)__ | __[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/achaamiii/)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/caffemocha0428)__

A Japanese pianist, composer and arranger affiliated with Legendoor.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/108529192) | [Website](https://www.art-setting.com/) | [Nico Nico](https://www.nicovideo.jp/user/662388)
Director of the Finishing Department at [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/).

[Official Website](https://www.mikanakashima.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/nakashima_mika_) | [Blog](https://lineblog.me/nakashimamika/) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/mikanakashima_official/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/mikanakashimaSMEJ)

She had always dreamed of becoming a singer since a child. She decided not to attend high school, and pursued her dream in a musical career.  

The very first demo tape she sent to a record company had given her the chance. She was chosen out of 3000 girls to be the heroine of the 2001 fall season drama “Kizudarake no Love Song (Scarred Love Song)” on Fuji TV. In November, she made her debut with Sony Music Associated Records, with the song “STARS," which was also the theme song of the drama. Her second single “CRESCENT MOON,” a groovy track with an 80’s flavor, was a limited product with only 100,000 copies. Amazingly, it sold out the first day of its release. In March 2002, she released her third single “ONE SURVIVE” and her first video “FILM LOTUS”; in May, her 4th single “HELPLESS RAIN”; in August, her 5th single “WILL."

In December 2006, Mika released “Hitoiro” for the NANA 2 movie under the name “NANA starring MIKA NAKASHIMA,” as well as a NANA album titled “THE END,” marking the conclusion of her association with NANA.

[Official Site](https://www.hyde.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/HydeOfficial_) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/hydeofficial) | [TikTok](https://www.tiktok.com/@hyde_official) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCPiJhfvRuQqQofd3xSZBQ1A)

Hideto Takarai, better known as HYDE, is a Japanese musician, vocalist, lyricist, record producer, actor and voice actor. He is best known as the vocalist for the rock band L'Arc~en~Ciel, as well as for the band Vamps. In the band L'Arc~en~Ciel he stylized his name as hyde, while in his solo projects and in the band Vamps he stylized it as HYDE. He is currently active in the band L'Arc~en~Ciel (1991–) under the name HYDE (2001–), while also a member of Vamps (2008–2017), who are currently on hiatus.
Shouji Hata is an Audio Engineer.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/50987970)

Also adept in CG work.
A former Studio Easter employee. Debuted as an art director on [Guin Saga](https://anilist.co/anime/5041/).

(Mecha) designer, occasional writer, for various series.




[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Joey__Jones)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/竹内志保)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/林直孝_(脚本家%29)

A scriptwriter and game scenario writer.

_Note: Not to be confused with the [animator/director](https://anilist.co/staff/110663/)._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tuka_trg)

After graduating from the Department of Art at Osaka University of Arts he joined Studio Ghibli as photographer and later transferred to Gainax, where he made his debut as director on some episodes of Evangelion.
    
He left Gainax in 2011 to found [Studio Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/Trigger) together with [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/Hiroyuki-Imaishi) and [Kazuya Masumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/150019/Kazuya-Masumoto). He is currently the CEO of the company.
Hiroshi Seko is a screenwriter.

[Twitter (shiimai)](https://twitter.com/shiimai) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=hiroyuki_imaishi+)
